DOMINION OF CANADA.

ORDER IN COUNCIL.

GOVERNMENT HOUSE, OTTAWA, NOVEMBER 14, 1882.

THIS EXCELLENTLY THE GOVERNOR-GENERAL IN GENERAL COMMAND,

WHEREAS the demands of pioneer communities prevail among new cattle being imported from the United States, and as in other more Eastern areas, orders have been sent from the State of Illinois to prevent further shipment except by the officers and men in charge of such institutions or places.

To the Commissioner of Agriculture of the United States, his place or places:

The Commissioner of Agriculture, by Proclamation of August 8, 1883:

The Commissioner of Agriculture, authority, will be directed to continue to take the following measures:

1. All mail cars carrying Canadian cattle shall not be allowed to cross the Canadian borders without the consent of the Provincial Directors of Agriculture.

2. Any special order made by the Commissioner of Agriculture shall not be permitted to enter Canada.

3. Any special order made by the Commissioner of Agriculture shall not be permitted to pass through either the Canadian border or the United States border.

4. Any animal found to be suffering from contagious disease shall be destroyed at once.

5. Any animal found to be suffering from any disease whatsoever shall be slaughtered at once.

6. Any animal found to be suffering from any disease whatsoever shall be slaughtered at once.

7. Any animal found to be suffering from any disease whatsoever shall be slaughtered at once.

PRINCE ALBERT TIMES AND SASKATCHEWAN REVIEW.

PRINCE ALBERT, SASK., FRIDAY, NOVEMBER 14, 1884.

$2.50 A YEAR.

TELEGRAPHIC.

By Special Telegraph to The Times.

NOVEMBER 14—Advice has been received from Missouri. It was reported that he had not been heard from during the summer. It is now known that he is recovering from his injuries.

We would advise Ladies to examine the newspapers from Albion Capa. For sale at Buffalo Hall.

We must apologise for the non-arrival of our paper on Friday last, the cause being our removal to our new offices, which are now being occupied.

On Saturday morning His Lordship the Bishop of Saskatchewan proceeded to the church at Regina. His Lordship spoke of the present conditions of the country and said that so much talk about the old scandals must cease. In his address he spoke very highly of His Excellency the Governor General.

There has been a great increase in the number of cases of Cholera in France, both in Paris and elsewhere.

No change has yet been made by the officials concerning the suspension of railway services. The suspension will continue until further notice.

The Catholic Bishop of Regina has issued a decree suspending the religious services for the month of December. 

John J. McKee, Clerk, Grey Council.

PUBLIC NOTICE.

All parties are hereby notified that the organization of the Lamport Institute has been officially sanctioned by the Provincial Government.

THE ISLAND LAKE PRESBYTERIAN CHURCH.

Sunday School Meeting.

A dispatch from Sir John Sara says—Greatly improved in health, will leave on the 20th next. Public and private meetings cancelled.

The minister of the H.M. New Brunswick has arrived.

The oldest parish priest, Rev. Father Christian, has been installed as vicar-general.

The Catholic Church celebrated her first jubilee this year, and we have every reason to believe that she will have a successful future.

The Scoroti church was consecrated recently.

CHIT CHAT LOCALS.

Gathered by our Reporters.

Cold weather has again set in.

In some of the northern school districts promised this fall.

FRIDAY, NOVEMBER 14, 1884

THE BEST POLICY.

Surprise is often expressed that in a district like ours which includes among its inhabitants so many who have been brought up in political life at least the same proportion of Conservatives as exists in other parts of the Dominion, so much dissatisfaction with the present Government should prevail. To go into an examination of the causes which have produced this state of public sentiment, and separate such as the people may blame themselves for from those which may not unreasonably be laid to the charge of the Government would be a work of time. We content ourselves at present with the assertion that the causes are of the two kinds indicated. We are of the opinion that the policy of the present Government is attributable to ignorance on the part of those in authority of the amount of feeling engendered by things which may pass unnoticed by them at the moment, but which are thought about, at all times, as being of no real moment. We infer from the fact that many of the things which cause intense irritation here, cannot possibly be of any importance to them, to induce, by instance, the risk of the alienation of the good will of the people generally. We believe it to be acting the part of true friendship to the Government to do as we are pleased to point out that in matters of what we have referred to, as may from time to time occur. It has fallen to us on several occasions when writing in our columns to call attention to what must be clearly kept in view, with regard to the peculiarity of the bearing upon our circumstances of the building of the C.P.R. Once more we put on record the fact that this undertaking is not near enough to us to lessen by a fraction the cost of freighting in our necessaries, while by putting places hitherto affording us a market for our surplus produce in easy communication with the town below, that market so vital essentially to our welfare has been developed. This advantage, however, does not actually seem to entitle us to special consideration at the hands of the Government, the more so when the amount of perseverance and endurance displayed by the company during its development under such circumstances is remembered. Now surely it is not asking much to demand that such supplies as are required by the Indians be purchased from us, instead of maintaining the Indians, which can be done by purchasing from us. Supposing we by no means admit the purchase of these supplies, then should not a little more thought be given to the matter than just to incur the slight extra expense in order to foster those settlers who have given up so much and endured so much in opening up this country, to valuable a country land as this vast territory? Beyond dispute this must be not only the most generous, but in the long run the best paying policy. That the Government will not do this, we do not deny, but hope that an extension of the policy will give us the much required enlargement of our markets. We must point out that the Government has acted with great distinctness, whatever the direction we receive, and that directions can only be made of real value to the community at large by the adoption of the only fair system by which competition is permitted to exist. That this policy must be the best for the Government requires no demonstration, and we may assure them it is the only one that can be acceptable to the people. If they desire that the contractors for their money may purchase must be made from the people, but it should be a part of the Government's policy to lend its aid and increase the wealth and power of any one who at the expense of others. We want to open competition, without favor, or if any be shown, that it be to those who will keep and circulate their money in the community. In a competitive field merchants must take much of their pay in produce, it is of the last importance that one should have as good a chance of converting the produce so taken into cash, as another, and that the money be given by mutual partiality to one, must necessarily end in the creation of a monopoly, with the most disastrous results to every member of the community. That in days gone by, the most important thing was the favor of one large interest in the Territories has been made with respect to land and money is the strong opinion of many, and any further extension of privilege in the same direction will be jealously watched for and most bitterly resented.

G. D. NORTHRAVES,
Watchmaker and Jeweller.

CORONER'S INQUEST

Early on Monday morning Inspector Howe was notified that the body of a man named William Denning had been found hanging from a beam in the house belonging to Mr. Alexander Campbell, former Justice of the Peace, 47, and Sergt. Brooks was at once sent to take charge of the case. The body was found hanging from a beam in the afternoon at the house of Alex. Campbell by the coroner of this district, Dr. J. A. Agnew, following instructions given him by Inspector Howe.

The body was found hanging from a beam in the house belonging to Mr. Alexander Campbell, former Justice of the Peace, 47, and Sergt. Brooks was at once sent to take charge of the case. The body was found hanging from a beam in the afternoon at the house of Alex. Campbell by the coroner of this district, Dr. J. A. Agnew, following instructions given him by Inspector Howe.

MEDICINE HAT.

Sergt. Major Wattam, with Sergt. Floyd and two constables passed here for Calgary on the 26th of October, on their way back to Medicine Hat.

ST. LOUIS, MISSOURI, U.S.A.
OUR COURTS.

One of those causes at work to produce strong dissatisfaction with and irritation towards the Government of this district is to be found in the lamentably defective nature of the arrangements made for the administration of justice, civil and criminal. The inconvenience, delay, loss and miscarriage of justice which may necessarily result from the irregularity and uncertainty—under the present system apparently unavoidable—with regard to holding courts by the stipendiary magistrate whose course bears with equal hardship on all sections of the community, although the force of contrast may render it peculiarly offensive to those who have, under their arrest herebefore where the legal machinery works with the utmost regularity.

The amount of detriment to the public interest pointed out very clearly in our columns at an earlier time, which happened last year, between the crises in the interval between the removal of Col. Richardson and the appointment of Judge Robson, was borne out by the fact that there was no impression that, with a little trouble and foresight on the part of those responsible, the annoyance might have been avoided.

This summer's matter of the telegraph operator, caused no need of inconvenience to the law-giving part of our community, and now again have we been most seriously deranged by what, surely, must be supposed to be the probable contingencies and with a just appreciation of the public interests at stake, to have allowed him reasonable time to complete his journey from Battleford to Regina, but by too late advertised for the holding of court, we must attribute to a visitation of Providence in the shape of snow storms, which deferred the opening from Monday until Friday last. With regard to legal perfunctoriness, impertinence, despatch in business, accompanied by patience in investigation, and personal dignity, in fact to all the elements which constitute a good court, we should certainly think so when we have Judge R. Dean on the Bench, whose tact is nothing left to be desired, but none the less may his usefulness be greatly impaired by want of promptness whether validable or not. This, which under any circumstances could not fail to be the case, is especially so when owing to the distance he must have as a rule to travel and the unusual difficulty in securing the attendance of sailors and their witnesses in a population to a considerable extent migratory, the miscarriage of justice must be in consequence of the impossibility of those at great sacrifice have put in an appearance at the appointed time hanging on to the neglect of all their other interests indispensable to their livelihood, even at the time when those intending to leave here desire to start, and those intending to stay here to fix up for the approach of winter, and in many cases owing to the absence of thoroughbred steers, it is peculiarly unfortunate. To catalogue the individual cases of hardship would be a lengthy process, and it must suffice to say that an inadequate availability of the services of the keeper of things is simply intolerable. The fact of the matter is that our district's present amount of law business—steadily on the increase imperceptibly during the administration here of a resident stipendiary magistrate—that such an appointment need entail upon the Government a cost, in proportion to the interests at stake, ridiculously small, is easily demon-
